text:
There are so many awesome reviews of this recipe that you may never even bother to read mine but . . . we have this at EVERY single family gathering. We have to plan the rest of the food around this recipe because the entire extended family insists upon this particular recipe. Others have brought different versions but they just don't cut it with the "fam." You cannot go wrong if you try this recipe. Don't subsitute cream of chicken or celery soup for the cream of potato. It's a key ingredient and worth the trip to the market to get it if you don't have it on hand.

text:
This is a wonderful casserole.  The first time I made this dish my boyfriend thought it was too rich.  He decided to give it one more try.  I made it this past weekend.  He loved it.  Instead of using the sharp cheddar, I used medium cheddar.  I also added 1/4c red bell peppers, 1/4c green bell peppers, and 1/4c onions, and 1/4c mushrooms.  Also after I serve this onto a plate, I grate some fresh parmesean cheese to give it a little kick.  The peppers added such a wonderful flavor to this dish.  This is going to be a favorite for a long time.  Enjoy.  Thank you Melissa!

text:
I followed the recipe precisely, and this was yummy.  I did cover loosely with foil after about 20 minutes when it looked like the edges were browning too early, but next time I'm just going to let it go.  I didn't think a cup of ham would be enough or that this would actually serve 12, but it was just right.  I used diced hash browns instead of the shreds, and shredded parmesan from a bag instead of the shaker can.  Next time I might throw in some chopped jalapenos or green chiles for more zip -- bacon crumbles would be good too -- and the earlier reviewer's breakfast burrito idea for leftovers also sounds fabulous!  This was super-easy to make up the night before.  Thanks!

I made this for a church group and got rave reviews, and many recipe requests. I agreed with other reviewers that it was very salty, if you can use any low sodium ingredients do so. To the reviewer whose results were soupy, I wonder if you might have used ready to serve, rather than condensed soup. Thanks for sharing this recipe! 
This is an addition to my original review. I recently made this again, I omitted the Parmesan cheese, instead topping it with an additional handful of cheddar. This eliminated the salt problem! Wonderful stuff, try it you will be pleased!

Excellent! I made this for a department breakfast at work and it was a hit. The only thing I changed is I did add 16oz of ham and one chopped green pepper.  Also, one major thing I would recommend is when you buy the frozen hash browns - make sure to *thaw them out and DRAIN THEM* before putting them in the pan.  Squeeze all the excess liquid out. That made a huge difference.  I am going to cook this for breakfast on Thanksgiving morning. Great recipe!

Good base recipe- but made quite a few additions.  I used potatoes Oâ€™ Brian, with the peppers and onions already in it. Instead of dicing the ham, I layered 4 thick cut, sliced, smoked pork chops on top. Added cheese and French fried onions on the top. This recipe needs seasoning for sure- pepper, paprika, a dash of cayenne, garlic power, and half of the cheese I used was pepper jack as well. This made it really flavorful and gave it more of a southwestern kick. Really, really good. **Update**- I have started making this with light sour cream, the "Healthy Request" version of soup, and 2% cheddar cheese and it turns out exactly the same.

text:
ILOVE this casserole and we also have it at every family brunch. Often I prepare it the evening before and either slow cook it in a crock pot or store it in the fridge until the next morning. Once I didn't have sour cream but I had 'HellavaGood' chip dip so I added that. It was great. We have also experiment with the cheeses using Swiss, Jarlsbery, Sargento's Italian blend. This casserole is very flexible and lends itself to experimentation. For the ham, I usually use leftovers from a spiral ham - it's more flavourful. I don't like using those little football hams -yuck. If you don't have a 'good' cooked ham, try substituting large diced chunks of peameal bacon that have been lightly sauteed. Sauteed onions are also an excellent addition. Customize this recipe to your family's and friend's taste!

I meant to rate this a long time ago. Fantastic as written, but I do add 1/8 tsp of onion powder and 1/8 tsp of garlic powder and 1/4 tsp of pepper. I don't use the shaker parmesan, but I buy the Kraft shredded parmesan over with the other shredded cheeses and it makes all the difference in the world. Amazing flavor. Don't use any other soup besides the potato...it is the exact right soup for this casserole.

I prepared this recipe for today's brunch with the women of my bible study group and not a drop was returned home!  I made a few changes to spice it up a bit, etc.  Used 8 oz versus 16 oz of sour cream.  Used 1 can crm/potato + 1 can crm/celery.  I omitted the ham. Pretty good, rave reviews from the husband. Because there were no eggs in the recipe, I make it feel more breafasty. After 45 minutes in the oven, I removed the casserole and created nine craters with the back of a spoon and cracked eggs into the craters. Then I put it back in the oven for the rest of the time. The result is soft, runny eggs, so you might have to leave it in the oven a little longer if you try this to make sure the eggs are cooked enough.

After the amount of reviews on here I'm probably not going to say anything new but - SERIOUSLY, YOU NEED TO MAKE THIS THE WAY IT'S WRITTEN BEFORE SWITCHING IT UP!!!  The Cream of Potato Soup really makes a big difference, members of my family have been making this for years but always with different kinds of soup (mushroom or chicken)and I liked it then and certainly wouldn't turn it down BUT the potatoe soup makes the difference, I don't know why and I don't care, from now on when I'm at family gatherings all I will think of is the fact that I've had better.  The next time I made it I added more ham, left out the parm and sprinkled bread crumbs on top and it was also amazing.  You can certainly do whatever you please for this recipe to meet your taste but DO NOT substitute out the soup!!
I really can't stress this enough... Don't do it!

Delicious as is.   I did take the advice not to substitute the potato soup (had to run to the store) and didn't need 12 servings so I halved the recipe.  I wanted a more complete breakfast dish so I shorted the sour cream by about a 1/2 cup and added 3 beaten eggs to the mixture.  Turned out really well with good texture.  May try adding some sauteed onion or jalapeno.  I think you could probably use sausage or ground beef for a lunch or dinner dish.  Very filling. Good job.  I will be making this again.

Update: Used mushroom soup, eggs and Greek yogurt/sour cream and browned the potatoes with onion and orange bell pepper before mixing together.  Great versatility in this recipe.  Lends itself well to whatever meat, seasoning and soup combination you wish to use.  Just be sure to maintain the liquid ratios.  Adding eggs will make the casserole light and fluffy.  Just beat them slightly before mixing with sour cream and soup. Husband thought this was really good and, as usual, topped his with Mexican hot sauce.

After reading many of the reviews, I made some changes, which made this was just okay/edible.  It would have been better without the changes.  I used 1 low-fat cream of mushroom, and 1 low-sodium cream of celery instead of cream of potato.  I added more cheese (1 cup more) and used about 8 oz. low-fat sour cream and about 4 oz. non-fat plain yogurt.  Also, I didn't use the parmesan.  I really did not care for it this way, so make your changes wisely!  If I had it to do over, I would use full-fat everything with extra cheese and 1 cream of mushroom & 1 cream of potato, plus pepper.  I'm sure it would be better this way.

text:
I think this might become a new favorite after a little tweaking! We unfortunately had to skip the ham (didn't have any on hand), but I did substitute some crumbled bacon in my half (my husband doesn't like bacon--can you imagine?).  We also added in about 3/4 cup freshly chopped Vidalia onion and 1/2 cup freshly chopped yellow bell pepper (b/c it was available). We sauteed the onion, pepper, and a bag of frozen Ore-Ida diced ("southern style") hash browns in a large pan for a few minutes (just until some of the potatoes began to brown) before mixing them in a large bowl with the rest of the ingredients.  After spooning the mixture into the baking dish, I used a fork to mix the bacon to my half. Then we sprinkled the Parmesan and a little extra cheddar on top.  Everything came out fine, but we both thought it needed more salt; we'll probably add extra Parmesan and season the potatoes in the saute pan next time. This kept well in the fridge for several days, and personally, I felt it got better each time I ate it! It was very easy to heat up in the microwave but took forever in the big oven.  I think next time we'll try substituting one can of cheese soup for one of the cans of cream of potato soup (as several have recommended). I also look forward to making this in the future with the cubed ham, and maybe I'll play with some other types of peppers and cheeses as well! Someone mentioned cooking this in a slow cooker, which I think would work well with this recipe!

Well my 13 almost 14 year old sister said it was better than a similar dish that my mom makes that is one of our family favorites, so I have to give it 5 starts.  No, this isn't healthy but it's nice for something special (I made for Easter brunch).

I did make some minor changes...

text:
By virtue of the high ratings and liking the ingredients listed I gave it a try.  Can't say it was all that wonderful. Perhaps I just prefer my hashbrowns crisp and this recipe of course doesn't facilitate that kind of dish. The amount of sour cream seemed high and taste stood out.
I would only try again with modification of cutting back on the sour cream a little bit and turning the mix towards the end to actually brown some of the potatoes.  It's a preference thing.  If you don't like your hashbrowns not brown then I would avoid this one unless you were going to turn the mixture at the end of cooking. Perhaps frequent turning under the broil setting.  It might be super for those who love sour cream and enjoy eating their hashbrowns without being crisp (the coating of cheese you put on the top hinders the ability to actually brown the potato part.   Perhaps I just like mine more done.  Another alternative one might try if they like a more cooked taste is set the temp to 400 and cook for 1:15.   It's probably not a bad one if you play with it a bit.  But as the directions are understand you will likely get what I just described. If you like it that way, great.  Obviously many people here did.   Don't expect this to have crisp potatoes and do expect a heavy sense of sour cream.  I mean 1lb of sour cream is hitting it a tad heavy in my opinion.  Good luck!

I added another tin of soup and more Greek yougert.. ummm no..... it would not set. I make this almost the same way except I am gluten intolerant so instead of using cream of soup (& sour cream), I make a white sauce (in a saucepan melt butter, add GF all purpose flour and slowly add milk add a bit of dry mustard and S&P to taste. I've also used mozzarella cheese when I was short on cheddar or marble - its an all around great recipe - easy to substitute your fave ingredients with

Thank you sooo much for sharing this recipe! I had seen this recipe here, wrote it down, tried it, and forgot to save it. So I hadn't been back to review it, but I had to make the effort.

This is THE best cheesy potato casserole ever! I use this recipe at least once a month, if not more. I especially like to make it when I'm trying to impress someone :D I make it with or without ham, with shredded hashbrowns or with southern (cube) hashbrowns, and with Cheddar or velveeta cheese. And I've actually never made it for breakfast.

All around, fantastic recipe that I will use regularly for years to come!

text:
This is a very good recipe. I used 16 oz. of sausage instead of ham/bacon and it turned out very tasty. I did throw a bit of sage into the sausage when cooking it, just because I like sage in my sausage. I also used onion and cheddar cheese soup as others had suggested (1 can cream of potato and 1 can cheddar cheese). One person commented that it was a bit dry and suggested more sour cream. I used about 1/2 cup of milk and that worked fine. I used "Simply Potatos" for my hashbrowns which is a refrigerated brand - not frozen. They worked well. This is a very rich dish and people who are willing to go off their low fat diets love it!  Big hit at a brunch!

text:
SO easy and delicious! Took it to work for a holiday breakfast, and then made it for our family Christmas brunch, too. Was a huge hit for both groups. I did make some changes--the recipe is very forgiving, so you can easily make adjustments each time you make it, to change it up a bit. This time, I added spicy Italian sausage (crumbled and cooked before adding to casserole), about 1/2 tsp dry mustard, and 2 Tbsp Worcestershire Sauce. Also used freshly grated Parmesan Reggiano--makes a huge difference in flavor compared to the canned or any pre-grated Parmesan (even though seemingly expensive for a block, it goes a long way and is worth the difference). Also listened to previous reviewers recommendations to be sure to use the Cream of Potato soup, not another flavor--definitely agree that this makes a big difference, too. Could certainly use other creamed soups in a pinch (have used both celery and chicken in the past), but potato is the best.

text:
I made it a point to read as many reviews as possible and took them all into consideration. If you're on a low sodium diet, this meal is not for you, however with my altercations, my family devoured it. I have an incredibly picky family to feed. Husband is a cook (but hates cooking at home), son 10 picky and never hungry, my 2 year old won't eat anything unless he watches me cook it.

1 can potato soup
1 C low fat sour cream
thawed hashbrowns
sharp cheddar 1 C (save some for top)
monteray/chedder mix 1 C
Mrs. Dash (original- I use this alot)
Garlic powder to taste
Freshly cracked Pepper
Sprinkle of Cumin

Mix it all up, top with sharp chedar and sprinkle with parmesan 375 for 1 hour. The boys were all incredibly happy and all had second and third helpings. My job was done

Until I had to prep the turkey spaghetti sauce for the veggie lasagna tonight.

Very tasty!  I took it to my office and it disappeared.  Highly recommended.  Having said that, while I intended to make no changes, I was overcome by events!  I went to the store and forgot to get ham.  So I ended up using some andouille sausage I had in the freezer.  I cut up two sausages (Johnsonville) and it wasn't enough. You couldn't really taste the meat.  I find this recipe to be incredibly versatile - I think you could use bacon, ham, sausage or even ground beef.  I'm guessing you really do need 8 oz. - I went light on the andouille since I didn't know how spicy it would be.  I also used O'Brien potatoes instead of regular hashbrowns.  An excellent change!  I used the cream of potato soup and all cheddar cheese.  Two cups in the mix and a then a cup spread on top instead of the parmesan.  I've also decided that if you take out the meat, the recipe would make a fantastic potato side dish.  Either way, a total keeper!

text:
This is a keeper--a real keeper! My hub said it was "Super! Super! Super!" I like to review the recipes just as they are written, but I did not have frozen hash browns and so, I had to improvise on that. The winter storm made us house bound and we wanted a wonderful morning breakfast; so I baked 5 large Russet potatoes the night before and cooled them in the refrig overnight. The next morning, I peeled the skins off and then grated them on my largest grater into a big bowl. I mixed all the other ingredients so they were well combined(oh, I did saute in 1 tsp butter the ham and added 1c finely chopped onions, just until the onions were translucent)and then gently folded into the grated potatoes.  I topped it with a combination of sharp cheddar cheese and freshly grated Parmesan.  (We think that the "Parmesan shaker can kind" makes things way too salty!)I was unsure how the potatoes would come out, but I am here to tell you, they were amazingly fluffy and light. I scrambled eggs on the side and we were off to the races. The result was a scraped clean, nothing, nada, the big goose egg--- pan with no leftovers in sight! It appears this will be the 'go-to' recipe for other events--church, school and work.

Made this as a main dish for Sunday dinner today with rave comments by all. Tweaked a bit for a healthier, somewhat more flavorful version as follows: Hash brown potatoes with peppers and onion; 1 can cream of potato soup, 1 can cream of onion soup; 1/2 can low fat milk;

As changed, Results superb! I'll be using this as a "signature" dish for future dinners and potlucks. Although the recipe would be a bit bland without addtions, I think this is great! The creamy consistency is so good!

Here's what I added:
*a bit of extra ham because I wanted to use it up
*garlic and onion powders
*cayenne pepper for a bit of zing
*black pepper
*mix of chedder and parm on top added at the last 20 minutes to prevent burning

Here's what I changed:
*substituted cream of celery and cream of chicken soups (low sodium)
*lite sour cream and only about 8oz since people said it was liquidy with all of it added.

Things I would recommend:
Crumbled sausage, green onions, other sauteed onions, parsley, zucchini, etc.

text:
I'll never put a can of soup in anything as a general thickener, and I don't use processed potatoes when my own fresh are so much better, but I still recommend the recipe.  Instead of using 2 cans of processed condensed soup, just cook 6 medium potatoes, cubed into about 1cm cubes, in boiling water for 10 minutes or until the potato is still intact at the edges but is tender to the point of a sharp knife.  Withhold 1/2 of water, drain the potatoes, and use the withheld 1/2 water, combined with 1C milk and 1C sour cream, for the sauce.  Of course I pan fried the ham with an onion and fresh herbs (1 sprig of chopped thyme, 1 sprig of chopped rosemary and 3 cloves of garlic) until brown first.  Delish!  Because you cooked the potatoes first in boiled water, the oven time of the recipe is cut by 1/2.  You can also finish the dish by broiling it for 5 minutes to give it a lovely brown crust.

text:
A+ and then some! Great recipe! 
After reading many reviews, here are my comments. 
I increased the recipe by half as I had five young men coming to dinner (total of nine guests). NO leftovers. Amount was just right at 1.5. For that size, I added 1/2 cup frozen peas, 1 cup finely chopped onion, 1 tsp smoked paprika and 1/2 tsp black pepper. I also used O'Brien (cubed) potatoes and 2 cups of ham. I mixed parmesan with cheddar 50/50 for the topping. I used reduced fat sour cream. I did cook it for about 20 minutes longer due to the increased amount. Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly. It definitely was NOT too salty. 
It was BEYOND delicious! GREAT way to use leftover ham! This recipe with the above personal adjustments is definitely 100% a keeper! Thanks for a great recipe!

I make this a lot and everyone loves it.  I cut the recipe in half and still use a 9 X 13 pan.  I prefer the fresh hash browns...not frozen.  I add 1/4 cup milk and 2 T melted butter.  I first mix the soup, sour cream, butter and milk together and add ground pepper.  I then add the cheese.  Mix and then the hash browns and ham.  I also top this with 1 cup crushed Lays potato chips. I don't always add the ham.  I let it rest for 15 minutes before serving.

text:
Very good! I purchased a ham steak some time ago (I was going to make a ham & potato chowder), but never got around to using it. While cleaning my freezer this weekend, I came across the ham I froze a couple months ago, so I decided to thaw it for this recipe. Although nearly perfect as is, I do think the ham / potato ratio was a bit off. You could easily double the ham and not have too much of it, IMHO. I pretty much followed POOBOO's directions to the letter except for halving everything (just serving my hubs and I) and subbing a 20 oz. bag of refrigerated Simply Potatoes brand diced potatoes with onions (I used 16 oz. worth of it) for frozen hash brown potatoes. Served with buttered corn and brown 'n serve dinner rolls on the side. If you're in need of a quick, inexpensive way to use up leftovers in your fridge, this is it. :) Thanks for sharing your recipe, POOBOO. I see myself making this for Easter brunch! :-)

text:
This was AMAZING! It was easy to make and very rich and creamy! I had to adjust the ingrediant amounts and cooking time due to the fact that we have no oven, so I bake things in a toaster oven. I did not add any ham and I mixed the parmesan in with everything else instead of sprinkling it on top. It didn't get soupy, or 'curdle'. I noticed in the reviews that a lot of people didn't care for the sour cream taste but I didn't find it overwhelming, perhaps because I really like sour cream. To get a nice cheesy crust on top I just broiled it for a few minutes after it had cooked through. We had the leftovers the next day and, as is usually the case, they were even better!

This recipe is seriously amazing. I make this dish as my "go to" casserole to bring to mom groups or other events. It is always a hit that everyone in the room is raving over. I'm serious. And everyone is asking for the recipe. The other reviewers are correct, I believe, when they say that the cream of potato is the secret ingredient that should not be altered. I agree. Also, the sour cream is a big part of the taste that otherwise you wouldn't even know it's there. But all the ingredients in this dish, though there are not many, do that magical thing in cooking, where they come together in the most perfect way. It happens here in this dish. And that's a nice thing when that happens. The ham is a great addition. In the video, they put the crumbled sort of parmesan cheese. I have never used that type in this dish. I use the pack of grated parmesan cheese which I think is a higher quality, like you would receive on top a dish in an Italian restaurant. But there is one thing I do that I think makes this dish even better.. I don't use the typical bag of frozen shredded hashbrowns. I use the Trader Joes  frozen Hash browns which are the type that come in little patties that you can pop in the toaster or bake in the oven and hold one in your hand. I use one and a half containers of that, which comes out to 32 ounces, as the recipe calls for. All I do is place the frozen hash brown patties/cakes onto a plate and microwave them for one minute. I made this for my family for dinner tonight to the tune of rave reviews!  Even my picky almost 3 year old ate it up!  I, however, was mixed on how I felt about it (hence the 4 stars).  On the pro side, it came together very quickly and easily, was very cheesy, and made enough to really feed up to 12 people.  Cons though, I just really felt like something was missing flavor wise...It just needed that extra "something."  Maybe next time I will add onions and peppers as others have suggested.  I also thought that for being in the oven an hour, it didn't seem hot enough...perhaps because of the frozen/cold ingredients.  I didn't think it was too salty as others thought, but I did reduce the amount of parmesan so that may have helped.  Like I said, the family loved this, but I do think heeding some of the other's advice might add a little extra needed flavor and really make this a mainstay recipe!

I made this twice. The first time I made it exactly as written, that's why it gets 3, maybe 4 stars. I thought it was missing a bit of depth and dynamic. For a 5 star recipe substitute one of the cans of potato soup for mushroom, add chopped onion, more ham (or ham and back bacon/peameal bacon since I had some left over from another recipe), and crumble some real bacon on top, make sure the bacon is fairly crispy first, then put on top for the last 10 minutes. I promise great results, and to wow your guests! Also, the second time, I made this the night before. Which made made it super easy in the morning to just pop it in the oven.

Like many of the reviewers, I made a few changes that are just a matter of taste.  I added onions to Southern style frozen hashbrowns & lightly browned them in olive oil with a bit of pepper.  I also fried about 16 ounces of diced ham before adding this to the potatoes.  I used one can of cream of onion & one can of cream of potato, however, I think next time I'll try just the potato. I served this with a Ramen Noodle Salad & it was a wonderful combination of flavors and textures.

I think that this is a 4 star recipes but with changes is a 5. I only used 1 can of soup and think I could have reduced the amount of sour cream also. I used 1/2 tsp of salt and one tsp each of pepper and garlic powder. I first sauteed an onion in  butter and added this in. I used about 1/2 cup total of parmesan cheese on top. I covered the top with foil toward the end of baking to prevent the cheese from becoming hard. This could have had another 8oz package of diced ham easily. All in all, the family really liked this and it was a hit. I wouldn't hesitate to make this without the ham for a delicious side dish to a ham dinner.

VERY good, Extremely easy, relatively inexpensive and makes plenty although I doubled the recipe for a family gathering and there wasn't a scrap left in the pan. Great for a potluck. I will DEFINETELY fix again and again. Could even leave out the ham and it would be great.  Thanks Melissa

text:
I needed to use up some ingredients that were taking up real estate in my fridge so I changed it up a bit to use them up. I had used part of my 30 oz. bag of hash browns so I probably only had about 20 oz. left. I left them to dry out in the fridge overnight the day before I used them. I used regular slices of ham (off a real ham) and chunked them  up and sauteed them to get a bit of color. I put the ham and the fat into the potato dish. I added about a tsp.  each of garlic and onion powder, and I used 1 can of cream of mushroom and 1 can of cream of chicken soup instead of cream of potato. I added an entire bag of red/green bell peppers and onions, salt and pepper to taste. I was a little short on the sour cream- probably only about 10 oz. left. Finally, I was out of parm and cheddar but I did have half a brick of Velveeta to use up so I melted that  with a little half and half and butter and added that. I topped off with some homemade Italian seasoned breadcrumbs and a bit of olive oil and it turned out creamy and rich and really yummy!

I used 3 cans of potatoe soup, 1/2 can of milk, also an extra 8oz of cubed ham,  added 1/2 cup mild cheddar cheese and added a little garlic salt, and parsley. Topped with Italian bread crumbs.  I suggest placing a cookie sheet underneath it to catch any spillover and it also will help keep the bottom from burning. My wife and I love this as do our 5 children. It also works good wrapped in a tortilla.

I usually have to make a main dish for church, and this dish goes faster than quick. I don't have left overs to bring home. This was a wonderful recipe.   I honestly thought just reading it, it sounded kind of bland and probably would not have even tried it were it not for the reviews.  So glad I tried it.  I used "Simply Potatoes", refrigerated hash browns rather than frozen.  I used the Southwest style with some peppers and onions in it.  I doubled the ham as I thought only 8 oz of ham for a 9x13 pan was kinda slim.  Only other change was I baked for 45 minutes before adding the Parmesan.  Had I put it on before baking, it would have burnt to a crisp.  15 minutes in the oven is plenty for the Parmesan.

It is a super simple recipe, took me something like 5 minutes to throw together which is great! I halved the recipe because there's just 2 of us and it was enough for 2 meals.  Didn't have sharp Cheddar Cheese so had to use whatever was in the refrigerator (think it was Colby/Cheddar). I added some garlic salt and a dash of minced onion along with a generous amount of fresh ground pepper and it was done and waiting in about 40 minutes using my convection/bake feature.  Actually could have pulled it out a little sooner as the top got pretty brown.  I will definitely be making it again because of ease of preparation plus it's not terribly expensive to make and most generally I have all the ingredients on hand.

text:
This went over well for a brunch but I made lots of changes after reading the reviews.  First I used O'brien potatoes cubed not shredded, added more spices (garlic and onion powder, paprika and pepper) and quickly browned the hash browns prior to adding them into the casserole mixture.  I think this helped the texture and prevented them from becoming mushy after cooking.  I substituted cream of mushroom with garlic for one can of the cream of potato (still used one can of the cream of potato, too).  I used one large Ham Steak and I browned it well, cubed it into pieces and added to the mix.  I used less cheese than stated and once the casserole was almost done, I added a bit more cheese and some french fried onions to the top of the dish and allowed to melt and brown a bit.  Every loved it, it was flavorful and the texture was nice without being mushy.  While my changes did add a bit of prep time, it was worth it for the final result.

text:
This recipe is good.  Very rich, very cheesy, very salty...all the not-so-healthy things we love.  The ham gets lost in the huge amount of hashbrowns.  I would use 16 oz (1 lb) next time.  I also used Bob Evans Seasoned (Shredded) Hashbrowns that you can find in the refrigerator section of the grocery store near the ready-to-eat items such as pre-packaged meatloaf, pot roast, mashed potatoes, etc.  I skipped the parmesan all together...that's a weird flavor to add to this recipe if you ask me.  The top of the casserole got nice and bubbly brown and so did the edge pieces (the best part in my opinion!!).  I also used one can of cream of mushroom and one can of cream of chicken since they make "healthy request" versions of these and they don't for cream of potato.  The point is...great recipe, and it's flexible so you can make alterations and it will still come out just fine.  Thanks!!! :)

text:
My family LOVED this casserole.  At first, I thought it might be too dry, but the hashbrowns cook down, and make quite a creamy sauce.  If you have kids that don't like "weird" stuff in their food, this is the casserole for them.  I recommend mixing the soup & sour cream separately from the rest, the adding in the cream mixture. It's alot to mix. My favorite part is the crunchy parmesan topping! My only modifications were to the cheeses.  Didn't have enough sharp cheddar, so I made up the difference with whatever was in my fridge.  Also, 1-1/2 cups of parmesan seemed like too much, so I used less.  Turned out perfect!

text:
The first time I tried this recipe I did exactly as recipe stated - I thought it was very blah - No flavor. I made it tonight and it was so much better! This is what I did - In a bowl mix soup,sour cream, Cheese, and 1 thinly sliced/chopped onion. Spray pan with Pam spray and put a layer of half of the hashbrowns - then half of the ham chunks - then half of the Soup/sourcream mixture. Then repeat layers. 10 minutes before it was ready I stirred everything together and baked for 10 more minutes. It was a huge difference - Definitely add extra ham and chopped onion in it for flavor.

text:
Well,  I've tried many breakfast casserole recipes.  And this is the keeper.  I took it to a brunch meeting and it was delicous and tastey looking with the golden crusted top.  I used fresh parmesean, which I highly recommend.  I agree with a previous member who thought you need to keep it uncovered the full hour.  The top gets so golden and good.     I really didn't alter anything in the recipe except I used one cream of onion and one cream of potato.  I probably used a little more ham than 8 oz. (used what I had frozen).  I don't know if I'd make it for dinner, since it is so rich.  But for a potluck where people tend to like the creamy, salty, gooey, rich stuff...this is perfect. It disappeared.  Thanks for a great recipe!!!

We had this for dinner tonight and it was delicious! Quite rich and creamy. Delicious!  Still smells great in the house!  My only complaint is that it came out a _bit_ too salty...but I'm sure I can adjust for that next time.  Like other reviewers, I used 8 oz. low fat sour cream, low sodium cream of celery and cream of mushroom soups, mixed in 2 eggs for binding, and added some onion, cayenne pepper and garlic powder to kick it up a bit. text:
Excellent! Served it at our Father's Day Brunch. I used 16 oz. breakfast sausage instead of ham and used 3 cups of cheddar and no parmesean. If you use obriean potatos you won't have problems with the potato lumps from the soup. I think adding the cheddar soup as others suggested would make it too cheesy. I would consider this more of a breakfast side dish than a main dish because theres not that much meat in it compared to the potatoes. I had to cook it an extra 10 minutes and it was slightly soupy when I removed it from the oven, but it set up beautifully within 5 minutes. Highly recommend as a side dish for breakfasts/brunches over 8 people.

okay, so this is obviously delicious per the flavorful ingredients (cheese, sour cream, cream of potato, more cheese). It's oh-so-creamy and cheese is gooey throughout. I used mild cheddar, but I wish I had used sharp instead (flavor would pop a bit more). With all that plain, white potato, stronger flavors can't hurt. None
text:
This is a great base recipe for a cheesy hash brown casserole. I substituted a 16 oz. kielbasa cut into small pieces for the ham and cream of chicken soup (instead of potato). I also added two teaspoons of dried onion flakes and one and a half teaspoons of powdered ranch dressing mix (like Uncle Dan's) to the potato mixture before baking. To top it off, I sprinkled one and a half cups crushed butter crackers (Ritz) over the casserole and added the parmesan cheese on top of that. Despite thawing the hash browns before using, this recipe needs at least 70-75 minutes to cook potatoes and meld flavors. My family enjoyed this dish, and my teenage kids said the crunchy top tasted like Cheese-it crackers; I will be making this again.

text:
First...this recipe is great as written.  Loved it!

As we all try substituitions, so did I! Some worked and some did not.

Other kinds of cheese: mixed reviews but sharp and parm work best. I do mix both in with the hashbrowns and save a little to sprinkle on top.

Other kinds of soup: nope! Cream of Potato is a must!

No meat or different meats: these all seem fine depending on what I've got on hand and what else is being served.  I've used sausage, bacon, and hamburger. Meatless is my most common variation here.

Sour cream sub: French onion sour cream dip adds some amazing flavor to this with no extra work since you can buy this right next to the sour cream. I do this all the time now.

Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Made early this morn at 7am & put in fridge until 10:45 am when we got back from church. Put in oven 45 mins. covered with foil. Then uncovered and baked another 10 mins. to brown the top a little. Since I could not get the"O'Brien"(Ore-Ida) hashbrowns, sauteed 1/2 sweet yellow onion and added 1/2 small can mild green chili's. Mixed the sour cream, potato soup, cheese and onion/chili's together first, then added hashbrowns & ham, then mixed. Also put Kraft Mexican Shredded cheese on top as the parmesan as others said would be too salty. (Do NOT add salt to this recipe as the condensed soup is already salty enough). Sprayed 13X9 glass dish with PAM and poured in mixture. I do think I could have made this the night before and put in fridge but reduced the cooking time the next morning to only 30 mins. as the hashbrowns would have thawed out by then. Note: my family all went back for 2nd helpings! Hooray!  A member of my family suggested adding PANKO bread crumbs on top next time which would have to be browned in butter first before putting on top.

text:
I made this recipe as is the first time and it was really good, but I always like adding my own spin to things. Instead of using frozen potatoes, I saw Bob Evans shredded potatoes and season them to my liking and Brook them in the oven just until they start to brown (for and added texture). I also sautee onion, green bell pepper, and mushrooms. I only use one can of cream of potato soup and substitute the other for cheddar cheese soup. The last thing I do differently, is use sharp cheddar as well as swiss cheese, it's the perfect combination and it's fantastic!

This recipe is fabulous just as is too!

Five stars with modifications. I used thick cut bacon, fried and then chopped up, instead of ham. Also I reduced the recipe by quite a bit and found it cooked better. If you do make the full recipe, make sure you put it in two baking dishes or one very large one so that it is not too thick (about 2 inches). If it's too thick it doesn't cook properly. This time I used about 1-2 cups hashbrowns, 1/2 cup sour cream, 1 cup cheddar cheese, half an onion and some cloves of garlic diced and sautÃ©ed, and one can of cream of mushroom soup.

text:
Easy, simple, and so adaptable.  I decided to use this for a dinner when hubby had to put something in the oven as I was coming home later than usual.  I made it up the night before so he only had to preheat the oven and put it in.  Unfortunately, I didn't have hash browns and rather than think of another recipe, I opted to use the mini tater tots I had on hand.  Also saw a bag of frozen peas and carrots, so I added part of that as well. but waited to add the Parmesan cheese until the casserole.  The hardest part was mixing it together as even using my largest bowl, the ingredients were heavy and it filled the bowl.  Decided to wait to add the Parmesan cheese until  I came home the next day and could see the casseroles just starting to bubble.  When the cheese was melted and just beginning to brown I removed it but waited about 10 minutes for the sauce to thicken, but garnished with just a little crumbled bacon.  I sent some over to a neighbor who lives alone and explained to her why It had mini tater tots.  She called later to say she loved that chunky texture and encouraged using them again rather than the hash browns the recipe listed.  So I the mistake turned out very well!

I cooked it as directed. Some of the hash browns were a bit crunchy, so i cooked for another half hour. I added a considerable amount of ham, as the 8 oz. just didn't seem enough... maybe this was the reason why the hash browns didn't cook through. Anyway, an additional half hour was what it needed. I also like that the recipe allows for seasoning to taste. It's not bland, but my daughters and I added a bit of salt and pepper. I'd rather add spices than find that the original recipe was over-salted, etc. I gave this recipe 4 stars because after cooking it longer, my daughters loved it! Thanks!

Delicious...now to be fair, i didnt follow the recipe exactly, but after trying it with my modifications, i know it would be just as delicious either way :)
i used one can of crm of pot and one of crm of nacho chs (that was all i had)...i added a small bag of bacon pieces (as well as the ham), didnt have parm. chs, so i added just a 1/2 cup of pepper jack with the reg. amt of cheddar chs.  and i also added some pepper.  i sprinkled french fried onions on the top for the last 10 minutes.  it was delicious!  i loved the little chunks of potato from the soup, so two cans would have been good, but i do like things a bit spicier, so i think the nacho chs substitute was a nice touch.  i also love parm chs, so i think that would be a nice addition, however, again, i like things spicier, so hence the pepper jack.  as for the bacon...need i explain?  everything goes good with bacon  :)   Thank you for a wonderful recipe!  it would make a great dish at any BBQ or party.

text:
On its own, this is a great starter recipe. I make several adjustments, but this has good fundamentals. It's bland, so season well. Experiment with different cheeses and meats. Bacon, Sausage, Eggs, Cheddar, Colby Jack, etc. The key to the flavor is the Cream of Potato soup, it is unique from the other cream of soups (chicken, mushroom, etc.). Gives it a nice tang when mixed with the sour cream. Great for breakfast or dinner.

text:
This recipe was defintely tasty.  The only change I made was I used fresh potatoes that I grated.  Now, that seems silly because frozen is so much easier, but I had potatoes I was trying to use up.  I grated them, soaked them, drained them, and wrung them out in a towel.  I did not precook them.  I mixed everything together and baked just like the recipe said. (I did add a little thyme, too, which was yummy).  The end result was yum!  I left off a star because I was hoping the hashbrowns would get brown and crispy on top - which may have happened if I had used frozen potatoes, I don't know.  But it was a little on the mushy side.  But the flavor was fantastic!!!  Will definitely try this again!

Thought this was pretty good.  Made mostly as written, but a few alterations.  My pkg of shredded hash browns was only 30 oz.  Let it thaw in the fridge for a few hours before mixing.  Used a bit more ham to make up for the missing potatoes and since I was using this as a main dish.  I used the real parmesian - not the stuff in the can.  It was expensive and I didn't feel that it added much to the dish.  Next time I will either leave it out completely or replace with a different cheese.  I served this with turkey sausage links on the side.  I can see how this would be good without the ham as a potato side dish.  Would go well with bbq.
